messages.content: Recent advancements in solar‑thermal energy storage span three complementary approaches. Molten‑salt technologies have incorporated novel nitrate‑based salts that raise energy density by over 10% while mitigating corrosion, thereby enhancing the feasibility of utility‑scale power generation. In parallel, hybrid materials that blend phase‑change substances with sensible‑heat salts achieve a 25% increase in volumetric storage capacity, facilitating more compact solutions for residential applications. Additionally, metal‑oxide thermochemical cycles, exemplified by copper‑iron redox reactions, deliver reversible storage of 3.2 MJ kg⁻¹ with greater than 85% stability across 500 cycles, positioning them as viable high‑temperature storage candidates. Together, these innovations broaden the technical toolkit for efficiently capturing and delivering solar heat across scales.
